name: Therapeutic Touch
summary: A contemporary energy healing practice involving non-contact or light-touch techniques intended to balance the human energy field and promote relaxation and healing.
description: Therapeutic Touch (TT) is a modern energy-based healing modality developed in the 1970s by Dolores Krieger, PhD, RN, and Dora Kunz. It is grounded in the concept that practitioners can attune to and influence a patient’s biofield (energy field) to promote healing. The technique involves centering by the practitioner, assessing energy flow with hands held near the body, and using sweeping or modulating movements to clear congestion and restore balance. TT is widely used by nurses and integrative health practitioners for pain relief, stress reduction, and enhancement of healing in various populations. While evidence is mixed and mechanisms remain theoretical, many patients report subjective benefits in relaxation, comfort, and pain relief.

practice_styles: Adapted therapeutic touch for palliative care
delivery_methods: Practitioner’s hands moved above or lightly touching the body
Energy field assessment and clearing motions
treatment_duration: Ongoing: weekly or as-needed sessions for chronic conditions
metadata.training_required: Certification courses available; often taught within nursing and holistic health programs
metadata.regulatory_status: Unregulated complementary practice; integrated into some nursing programs

contraindications: Relative: skepticism or discomfort with energy healing approaches
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Very safe; no known physical risks. Psychological risks are minimal but may include disappointment if expectations are unrealistic.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Low to moderate – some supportive findings for pain, anxiety, and well-being, but systematic reviews cite methodological limitations.

sections.text: Therapeutic Touch is based on the theoretical premise that human beings possess an energy field (biofield) that can be modulated by trained practitioners. The practitioner enters a meditative, centered state, assesses perceived energy imbalances, and uses hand movements near the body to redistribute or balance energy. While unproven in biomedical terms, proposed mechanisms include placebo effects, relaxation response, autonomic modulation, and therapeutic presence.

sections.preparation: Quiet environment, patient consent, practitioner centering and intention setting.
procedure: Practitioner centers through deep breathing or meditation.
Hands are moved slowly 2–6 inches above the body to assess energy flow.
Sweeping or modulating hand motions are used to clear congestion and balance energy.
Session concludes with grounding and reassessment of comfort levels.
sections.frequency: Weekly or as-needed depending on condition and goals.
sections.total_treatment_time: Flexible; often used as supportive adjunct to medical care.

sections.total_treatment_cost: Varies; often adjunctive with low ongoing cost

items: Therapeutic Touch is frequently used by nurses within integrative and palliative care settings.
Evidence supports relaxation and patient-reported comfort, though not definitive for physiological outcomes.
Should be presented as supportive, not curative.
Distinct from but related to other energy modalities like Healing Touch and Reiki.
